description: In his final game before the NBA shut down, Zion Williamson scored 23 points, made 9 of 15 shots, dunked six times and grabbed seven rebounds. Ja Morant, who did it 17 times, and Kendrick Nunn, who accomplished it 15 times, were only ahead of Williamson in that category because they played 40 and 43 more games, respectively. text:
In his final game before the NBA shut down, Zion Williamson scored 23 points,
made 9 of 15 shots, dunked six times and grabbed seven rebounds.

For most rookies, it would've been an exceptional outing. For the Pelicans'
19-year-old power forward, it was a run-of-the-mill performance.

In 19 games, Williamson scored 20 or more points and shot 50% or better from
the field 14 times -- the third-most times among all rookies. Ja Morant, who
did it 17 times, and Kendrick Nunn, who accomplished it 15 times, were only
ahead of Williamson in that category because they played 40 and 43 more games,
respectively.

Williamson was rolling when the league was forced to suspend play indefinitely
in mid-March. Can he pick up where he left off? Or will it take him time to
rediscover that rhythm? From a Pelicans perspective, those are among the most
significant questions as the NBA heads to a vote Thursday to finalize a plan
to resume the season.

The NBA is expected to ask 22 teams to finish the season at ESPN's Wide World
of Sports Complex near Orlando, Florida. Under this "playoffs plus" model, the
top eight teams in each conference along with Portland, New Orleans,
Sacramento, San Antonio, Phoenix and Washington will be invited. There will
reportedly be eight regular-season games and a play-in tournament between the
eighth and ninth seeds to finalize the postseason picture.

Williamson missed the first three months of the season recovering from a knee
injury, got 1 1/2 months of games under his belt and then, like most NBA
players, has been confined to his home for the past three months. How will he
reacclimate to the grind

professional basketball after so much time off? The Pelicans will be
monitoring closely.

Here are four other big-picture questions as the NBA prepares to ramp back up.

How will the race for the eighth seed be determined?

Privately, the Pelicans liked their chances of nabbing the Western
Conference's final playoff spot before the season shut down. They were finally
healthy and had one of the easiest closing stretches in the NBA, with 15 of
their final 18 games against teams with losing records. They were confident
they could close the 3 1/2 -game gap between them and the Grizzlies, who were
banged up and had a difficult closing stretch.

Here's how the race for the eighth seed works now: After eight regular-season
games, the NBA will hold a play-in tournament between the teams in eighth and
ninth in each conference, but only if the team in ninth is within four games
of the team in eighth. The team in ninth must then beat the team in eighth
twice in a row.

Hypothetically, let's say the Pelicans hold off the Trail Blazers, Kings and
Spurs for the ninth seed. (No small task.) They go 6-2 in their remaining
regular-season games and are 2 1/2 games back of the Grizzlies, who remain
eighth. They must beat the Grizzlies twice in a row to advance. If they win
the first game of the play-in tournament but lose the second, they are done.
The Grizzlies would only have to win one game of that two-game set.

Why 22 teams instead of 16?

The cleanest pathway to finishing the season is going straight to the
playoffs. Each NBA team is expected to travel to Florida with 35 people.
Concluding the season with 16 teams instead of 22 teams would mean 210 fewer
bodies on campus. That seems significant if the NBA wants to do everything it
can to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

Why mess with regular-season games? A play-in tournament? Six more teams than
absolutely necessary? The answer is simple: money.

"The revenue, I'm told, from just having the 16 and going to the playoffs
versus 22 and having the play-in and regular-season games (is) several hundred
millions more to teams," ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski said on SportsCenter. "And
that is absolutely a factor in this."

The NBA is trying to do whatever it can to soften the financial blow the
coronavirus has administered.

When will the season conclude?

The NBA season could run well into football season. On Tuesday, ESPN reported
Game 7 of the Finals would take place Oct. 12, the same date the Saints are
supposed to face the Chargers on Monday Night Football. Finishing the
abbreviated regular season and playoffs will take a minimum of two months.

The start of the 2020-21 season will be pushed back until December at the
earliest, which means that next year's playoffs won't begin until July. Start
mentally preparing now for the NBA's most important games to take place during
the dog days of summer.

Where do teams go from here?

The next step is for teams to recall players to their home markets so they can
begin practicing. Right now, practice facilities are only open for voluntary
individual workouts. No more than four players are allowed inside at one time.
At the Pelicans' practice facility in Metairie, only two baskets are available
for players to shoot on.

Teams will effectively have to hold a second training camp to get players back
into basketball shape. In April, Pelicans coach Alvin Gentry estimated that
could take "20 to 30 days."

Last month, executive vice president of basketball operations David Griffin
said a little more than half of the Pelicans' players were in the New Orleans
area. In the coming weeks, expect players who were quarantining outside of
market to trickle back to Louisiana so the Pelicans can restart the process of
trying to fight for a playoff spot.

title: Pelicans will be part of NBA restart
html:
In his final game before the NBA shut down, Zion Williamson scored 23 points, made 9 of 15 shots, dunked six times and grabbed seven rebounds.

For most rookies, it would've been an exceptional outing. For the Pelicans' 19-year-old power forward, it was a run-of-the-mill performance.

In 19 games, Williamson scored 20 or more points and shot 50% or better from the field 14 times -- the third-most times among all rookies. Ja Morant, who did it 17 times, and Kendrick Nunn, who accomplished it 15 times, were only ahead of Williamson in that category because they played 40 and 43 more games, respectively.

Williamson was rolling when the league was forced to suspend play indefinitely in mid-March. Can he pick up where he left off? Or will it take him time to rediscover that rhythm? From a Pelicans perspective, those are among the most significant questions as the NBA heads to a vote Thursday to finalize a plan to resume the season.

The NBA is expected to ask 22 teams to finish the season at ESPN's Wide World of Sports Complex near Orlando, Florida. Under this "playoffs plus" model, the top eight teams in each conference along with Portland, New Orleans, Sacramento, San Antonio, Phoenix and Washington will be invited. There will reportedly be eight regular-season games and a play-in tournament between the eighth and ninth seeds to finalize the postseason picture.

Williamson missed the first three months of the season recovering from a knee injury, got 1 1/2 months of games under his belt and then, like most NBA players, has been confined to his home for the past three months. How will he reacclimate to the grind

professional basketball after so much time off? The Pelicans will be monitoring closely.

Here are four other big-picture questions as the NBA prepares to ramp back up.

How will the race for the eighth seed be determined?

Privately, the Pelicans liked their chances of nabbing the Western Conference's final playoff spot before the season shut down. They were finally healthy and had one of the easiest closing stretches in the NBA, with 15 of their final 18 games against teams with losing records. They were confident they could close the 3 1/2 -game gap between them and the Grizzlies, who were banged up and had a difficult closing stretch.

Here's how the race for the eighth seed works now: After eight regular-season games, the NBA will hold a play-in tournament between the teams in eighth and ninth in each conference, but only if the team in ninth is within four games of the team in eighth. The team in ninth must then beat the team in eighth twice in a row.

Hypothetically, let's say the Pelicans hold off the Trail Blazers, Kings and Spurs for the ninth seed. (No small task.) They go 6-2 in their remaining regular-season games and are 2 1/2 games back of the Grizzlies, who remain eighth. They must beat the Grizzlies twice in a row to advance. If they win the first game of the play-in tournament but lose the second, they are done. The Grizzlies would only have to win one game of that two-game set.

Why 22 teams instead of 16?

The cleanest pathway to finishing the season is going straight to the playoffs. Each NBA team is expected to travel to Florida with 35 people. Concluding the season with 16 teams instead of 22 teams would mean 210 fewer bodies on campus. That seems significant if the NBA wants to do everything it can to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

Why mess with regular-season games? A play-in tournament? Six more teams than absolutely necessary? The answer is simple: money.

"The revenue, I'm told, from just having the 16 and going to the playoffs versus 22 and having the play-in and regular-season games (is) several hundred millions more to teams," ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski said on SportsCenter. "And that is absolutely a factor in this."

The NBA is trying to do whatever it can to soften the financial blow the coronavirus has administered.

When will the season conclude?

The NBA season could run well into football season. On Tuesday, ESPN reported Game 7 of the Finals would take place Oct. 12, the same date the Saints are supposed to face the Chargers on Monday Night Football. Finishing the abbreviated regular season and playoffs will take a minimum of two months.

The start of the 2020-21 season will be pushed back until December at the earliest, which means that next year's playoffs won't begin until July. Start mentally preparing now for the NBA's most important games to take place during the dog days of summer.

Where do teams go from here?

The next step is for teams to recall players to their home markets so they can begin practicing. Right now, practice facilities are only open for voluntary individual workouts. No more than four players are allowed inside at one time. At the Pelicans' practice facility in Metairie, only two baskets are available for players to shoot on.

Teams will effectively have to hold a second training camp to get players back into basketball shape. In April, Pelicans coach Alvin Gentry estimated that could take "20 to 30 days."

Last month, executive vice president of basketball operations David Griffin said a little more than half of the Pelicans' players were in the New Orleans area. In the coming weeks, expect players who were quarantining outside of market to trickle back to Louisiana so the Pelicans can restart the process of trying to fight for a playoff spot.
